stem: The nurse is applying external fetal monitoring. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Adjust the belts and verify that the FHR is distinct from the maternal pulse.
Perform Leopold maneuvers to identify the fetal position (back, head, buttocks).
Place the US transducer over the area corresponding to the fetal back.
Apply conducting gel to the ultrasound (US) transducer.
Place the tocotransducer (toco) over the uterine fundus.

rationale.correct: External monitoring tracks fetal well-being and contraction patterns. (1) Leopold maneuvers ensure you know where the baby is. (2/3) The fetal back is the best place to hear the heart. (4) The fundus (top of the uterus) is where contractions are most easily detected. (5) Final verification avoids misinterpreting maternal data as fetal.
rationale.incorrect: Placing the ultrasound transducer near the mother's pubis if the baby is breech will result in a poor signal.
clinicalPearls: If the fetal heart rate is heard loudest in the upper quadrants, the fetus is likely in a breech position.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'UA (Ultrasound) for back, TOCO for top (Fundus)'. Contractions always start at the top.

reviewUnits.heading: Intrapartum Fetal Monitoring
reviewUnits.body: Nurses interpret FHR patterns (accelerations, decelerations) and contraction frequency/duration to assess fetal oxygenation.
